sections.content:
The Präsens tense in German direclty corresponds to the present tense in English, as it is used to describe actions that are happening right now or habitual actions.
However, since in German the future tense is rarely used and the present continuous does not exist, it can also be used to describe future actions or actions happenning now with continuation on the future. The Präsens should be the first tense to learn when starting to learn German.

German is difficult on some aspects, but the most often used tenses are easier to learn! With the Präsens, you are getting 4 tenses in one: present, present continuous, present perfect and in some cases future!    🎉

items.text: Present Actions: Describing actions happening in the present.
Habitual Actions: Expressing routine or habitual actions.

example.text: Ich trinke jeden Morgen Kaffee.

items.text: General Truths: Stating facts or general truths.
Actions already started and still happening: In english we would use the present perfect tense: 'He has been playing...'.

example.text: Er arbeitet seit 3 monate ins Kino.
example.translation: (He has been working in the cinema for 3 months.)
